Poverty and inequality in France reach highest levels in 30 years
subhead: France's poverty rate reached 15.4% in 2023, its highest level since records began in 1996, according to data from the national statistics institute. The gap between the wealthiest and poorest 20% has widened, approaching levels last seen in the early 1970s.

headline: Texas floods: Over 160 people still listed as missing
London hopes for a shift in French immigration policy in the Channel
How Israel tracked down and assassinated scientists involved in Iran's nuclear program
subhead: Israel's attacks in June killed 16 leading researchers involved in Iran's efforts to develop an atomic bomb. Some of them had been under Israeli intelligence surveillance for two decades. With their deaths, Israel believes it has dealt the most decisive blow yet to Tehran's military nuclear program.

headline: China's 'black decade' for human rights lawyers
subhead: On July 9, 2015, Chinese authorities launched a sweeping crackdown on lawyers who dared to defend critics of the regime. Ten years later, the legal profession's room for maneuver has never been narrower.

headline: From 'Amsterdam' to 'Ne me quitte pas,' Jacques Brel's songs take center stage in Avignon Festival
subhead: At the Carrière de Boulbon, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, accompanied by Solal Mariotte, brings 26 classics by the Belgian singer to life through dance, sometimes risking an overly literal interpretation of their message.

headline: In Greece, migrant registration sites 'have shifted from a jungle model to a prison model'
subhead: '2015-2025: Europe's migration crisis' (4/5). 'Hotspots,' originally conceived as migrant registration sites, have gradually turned into closed detention centers, such as on the island of Samos, where asylum seekers now live in isolation.

France will lend Bayeux Tapestry to the UK, Macron announces
subhead: While local authorities hailed the decision, conservators warned of the risks of moving such a fragile work across the Channel.

headline: Iranian photographer Forough Alaei portrays life during the war: 'Nothing will ever be the same again'
subhead: After the first Israeli bombings in Iran, Iranian photographer Forough Alaei left Tehran to take refuge with her family on the Caspian Sea coast. She documented those days when war plunged them into the unknown.

headline: Tax on ultra-rich: 'France has the opportunity to lead the way,' say Nobel Prize-winning economists
subhead: As public deficits balloon and extreme wealth explode, creating a minimum tax on the assets of billionaires should be a priority, argue seven Nobel Prize-winning economists in an op-ed for Le Monde.
